trans-unit.source: Use Active Directory for authentication in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Use Active Directory for authentication in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn the different authentication and authorization options for line-of-business applications that are deployed to Azure App Service Web Apps
trans-unit.target: Learn the different authentication and authorization options for line-of-business applications that are deployed to Azure App Service Web Apps

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title> enables enterprise line-of-business application scenarios by supporting single sign-on (SSO) of users whether they access the application from your on-premises environment or the public internet.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title> enables enterprise line-of-business application scenarios by supporting single sign-on (SSO) of users whether they access the application from your on-premises environment or the public internet.

trans-unit.source: It can be integrated with <linkText>Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title> (AAD) or an on-premises secure token service (STS), such as Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS), to authenticate your internal Active Directory (AD) users and authorize them properly.
trans-unit.target: It can be integrated with <linkText>Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title> (AAD) or an on-premises secure token service (STS), such as Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS), to authenticate your internal Active Directory (AD) users and authorize them properly.

trans-unit.source: With a few clicks of a button, you can enable authentication and authorization for your web app.
trans-unit.target: With a few clicks of a button, you can enable authentication and authorization for your web app.

trans-unit.source: The checkbox style configuration in every Azure web app provides basic access control for your line-of-business web app.
trans-unit.target: The checkbox style configuration in every Azure web app provides basic access control for your line-of-business web app.

trans-unit.source: It does so by enforcing HTTPS and authentication to an Azure AD tenant of your choice before granting users access to your web app content.
trans-unit.target: It does so by enforcing HTTPS and authentication to an Azure AD tenant of your choice before granting users access to your web app content.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Web Apps Authentication / Authorization</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Web Apps Authentication / Authorization</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This feature is currently in preview.
trans-unit.target: This feature is currently in preview.

trans-unit.source: In many scenarios, you want to customize the authentication and authorization behavior of the application, such as a login and logout page, custom authorization logic, mult-tenant application behavior, and so on.
trans-unit.target: In many scenarios, you want to customize the authentication and authorization behavior of the application, such as a login and logout page, custom authorization logic, mult-tenant application behavior, and so on.

trans-unit.source: In these cases, it may be better to configure authentication and authorization manually for greater flexibility of its features.
trans-unit.target: In these cases, it may be better to configure authentication and authorization manually for greater flexibility of its features.

trans-unit.source: Below are two main options
trans-unit.target: Below are two main options

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure AD</linkText><title></title> - You can implement authentication and authorization for your web app with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure AD</linkText><title></title> - You can implement authentication and authorization for your web app with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Using Azure AD as the identity provider has the following characteristics:
trans-unit.target: Using Azure AD as the identity provider has the following characteristics:

trans-unit.source: Supports popular authentication protocols, such as <linkText>OAuth 2.0</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>OpenID Connect</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>SAML 2.0</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Supports popular authentication protocols, such as <linkText>OAuth 2.0</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>OpenID Connect</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>SAML 2.0</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For the complete list of supported protocols, see <linkText>Azure Active Directory Authentication Protocols</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the complete list of supported protocols, see <linkText>Azure Active Directory Authentication Protocols</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Can use an Azure-only identity provider without any on-premises infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Can use an Azure-only identity provider without any on-premises infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Can also configure directory sync with an on-premises AD (managed on-premises).
trans-unit.target: Can also configure directory sync with an on-premises AD (managed on-premises).

trans-unit.source: Azure AD with directory sync from your on-premises AD domain enables a smooth SSO experience to your web app when AD users access from the intranet and the internet.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD with directory sync from your on-premises AD domain enables a smooth SSO experience to your web app when AD users access from the intranet and the internet.

trans-unit.source: From the intranet, AD users can automatically access the web app through Integrated Authentication.
trans-unit.target: From the intranet, AD users can automatically access the web app through Integrated Authentication.

trans-unit.source: From the internet, AD users can log into the web app using their Windows credentials.
trans-unit.target: From the internet, AD users can log into the web app using their Windows credentials.

trans-unit.source: Provides SSO to <linkText>all applications supported by Azure AD</linkText><title></title>, including Azure, Office 365, Dynamics CRM Online, Microsoft Intune, and thousands of non-Microsoft cloud applications.
trans-unit.target: Provides SSO to <linkText>all applications supported by Azure AD</linkText><title></title>, including Azure, Office 365, Dynamics CRM Online, Microsoft Intune, and thousands of non-Microsoft cloud applications.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD delegates management of <linkText>relying party</linkText><title></title> applications to non-administrator roles, while application access to sensitive directory data must still be configured by global administrators.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD delegates management of <linkText>relying party</linkText><title></title> applications to non-administrator roles, while application access to sensitive directory data must still be configured by global administrators.

trans-unit.source: Sends a general-purpose set of claim types for all relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: Sends a general-purpose set of claim types for all relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: For the list of claim types, see <linkText>Supported Token and Claim Types</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the list of claim types, see <linkText>Supported Token and Claim Types</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Claims are not customizable.
trans-unit.target: Claims are not customizable.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure AD Graph API</linkText><title></title> enables application access to directory data in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure AD Graph API</linkText><title></title> enables application access to directory data in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>On-premises secure token service (STS), such as AD FS</linkText><title></title> - You can implement authentication and authorization for your web app with an on-premises STS like AD FS.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>On-premises secure token service (STS), such as AD FS</linkText><title></title> - You can implement authentication and authorization for your web app with an on-premises STS like AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Using on-premises AD FS has the following characteristics:
trans-unit.target: Using on-premises AD FS has the following characteristics:

trans-unit.source: AD FS topology must be deployed on-premises, with cost and management overhead.
trans-unit.target: AD FS topology must be deployed on-premises, with cost and management overhead.

trans-unit.source: Best when company policy demands that AD data be stored on-premises.
trans-unit.target: Best when company policy demands that AD data be stored on-premises.

trans-unit.source: Only AD FS administrators can configure <linkText>relying party trusts and claim rules</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Only AD FS administrators can configure <linkText>relying party trusts and claim rules</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Can manage <linkText>claims</linkText><title></title> on a per-application basis.
trans-unit.target: Can manage <linkText>claims</linkText><title></title> on a per-application basis.

trans-unit.source: Must have a separate solution for accessing on-premises AD data through the corporate firewall.
trans-unit.target: Must have a separate solution for accessing on-premises AD data through the corporate firewall.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title>
